references.N99WRI01USGP: WRIGHT, J.L. 1999. Winter home range and habitat use by sympatric fishers (Martes pennanti) and American martens (Martes americana) in northern Wisconsin. Masters thesis. University of Wisconsin, Stevens Point, Wisconsin.
references.A08BAL02USGP: Baldwin, R.A. and L.C. Bender. 2008. Distribution, occupancy, and habitat correlates of American martens (Martes americana) in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado. Journal of Mammalogy, 89(2):419-427.
references.A09KIR01USGP: Kirk, T.A. and W.J. Zielinski. 2009. Devleoping and testing a landscape habitat suitability model for the American marten (Martes americana) in the Cascades mountains of California. Landscape Ecology, 24:759-773.
references.N03FEC01USGP: Fecske, D.M. 2003. Distribution and abundance of American martens and cougars in the Black Hills of South Dakota and Wyoming. Ph.D. dissertation. South Dakota State University. 171 pp.
references.N03SLA01USGP: Slauson, K.M. 2003. Habitat selection by American martens (Martes americana) in coastal northwestern California. M.S. Thesis. Oregon State University. 112 pp.
references.A07DUM01USGP: Dumyahn, J.B., P.A. Zollner, and J.H. Gilbert. 2007. Winter home-range characteristics of American marten (Martes americana) in northern Wisconsin. American Midland Naturaist, 158(2):382-394.
references.R94RUG01USGP: Ruggiero, L.F., K.B. Aubry, S.W. Buskirk, L.J. Lyon, and W.J. Zielinski. 1994. The scientific basis for conserving forest carnivores: American marten, fisher, lynx and wolverine in the Western United States. USDA Forest Service general technical report RM-254.
references.A87CLA01USGP: Clark, T.W., E. Anderson, C. Douglas, and M. Strickland. 1987. Martes americana. Mammalian Species, 289:1-8.
references.W10STO01USGP: Stone, Katharine. 2010. Martes americana. In: Fire Effects Information System, [Online]. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory (Producer). Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/
references.N81BUR01USGP: Burnett, G.W. 1981. Movements and habitat use of American marten in Glacier National Park, Montana. M.S. Thesis. University of Montana, Missoula. 130 pp.
references.A97CHA01USGP: Chapin, T.G., D.J. Harrison, and D.M. Phillips. 1997. Seasonal habitat selection by marten in an untrapped forest preserve. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 61(3):707-717.

habitat_description:
Martes Americana inhabits mature, mesic forests, with large diameter trees, high canopy cover, and a complex understory and groundcover structure (Burnett, 1981; Clark et al., 1987; Ruggiero et al., 1994; Chapin et al. 1997; Kirk and Zielinski, 2009). Martens avoid open areas, grasslands, and clearcuts (Clark et al., 1987).

Those west of the Great Plains are found almost exclusively in coniferous forest (Clark et al., 1987; Buskirk et al., 1989; Ruggiero et al., 1994), though occasionally in mixed forests with aspen, birch, and/or cottonwood (Kirk and Zielinski, 2009; Stone, 2010). These western populations avoid xeric sites and ponderosa pine, douglas-fir, juniper, and pinyon woodlands and forests (Buskirk et al., 1989; Buskirk and Ruggiero, 1994; Ruggiero et al., 1994; Stone, 2010).

In the Great Lakes region, the species prefers mature, large-diameter, upland, mesic hardwood forests and occasionally uses upland conifer or mixed forests (Wright, 1999; Dumyahn et al., 2007). Similarly, in New England and the maritime provinces, martens display no preference for coniferous forests, given high canopy cover and tree heights > 12 m (Chapin et al., 1997).
